title: Ability to perform actions (Tweet, Retweet, DM) and other actions, unauthenticated, on any account with SMS enabled.

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

vulnerability_information:
**Summary:** By knowing the mobile phone number associated with a Twitter account, or by using random mobile phone numbers! It is possible to perform the following actions against a target without their knowledge or interaction. With no account takeover scenario.

It's a case of, if I know the mobile number... I can control basic functions of the account.

I can do everything that is listed here: https://help.twitter.com/en/using-twitter/sms-commands on an account, completely unauthenticated.


## Steps To Reproduce:

(Add details for how we can reproduce the issue)

  1. Spoof target number, send an SMS to a special short code for the geographical location, as seen here: https://help.twitter.com/en/using-twitter/supported-mobile-carriers


## Impact: Massive. I can remove the SMS two factor of the account. I can DM people without them knowing. If I had the mobile number of Donald Trump, I could send Tweets as him... There is so much wrong here. 

## Supporting Material/References:

  * List any additional material (e.g. screenshots, logs, etc.)

https://twitter.com/___Sh4rk___/status/1076204152546619392 this is a tweet I sent from my close friends account. She did not reveal her password or authenticate it at all.

## Impact

Remove 2FA

Tweet on someones behalf.

DM Someone.

Delete someones tweets

Turn off all phone SMS notifications

Follow people

Unfollow people.

Block/Report people - with a little script I could get 10000 phone numbers all reporting innocent tweets. Controlling media etc

More stuff really.

activities.message:
@antisocial_eng, thank you for your report.

As you note, we have a blog post from 2012 discussing these sorts of known SMS weaknesses in non-shortcode countries: https://blog.twitter.com/engineering/en_us/a/2012/twitter-and-sms-spoofing.html. Are you able to demonstrate this issue on an account/phone number registered via a shortcode (such as a US number), or is this limited to numbers registered via longcode such as the UK 3 network?

Also, please note that we have an average HackerOne response time of 1 to 2 business days, and since you reported this issue on a Friday before a long holiday weekend, it's typical for us to not respond until the next business day (e.g. today). While this issue is fairly widely known (and thus your blog post doesn't really disclose anything new), we'd normally consider such disclosure to fall outside of HackerOne's published responsible disclosure practices (https://www.hackerone.com/disclosure-guidelines), thus making this report ineligible for a bounty. In the future, we'd appreciate it if you'd stick to the published HackerOne disclosure process.

Please let us know if you are able to demonstrate this issue on numbers from shortcode based accounts or otherwise bypass the protections mentioned in https://blog.twitter.com/engineering/en_us/a/2012/twitter-and-sms-spoofing.html. Otherwise, we'll close this out as a duplicate/known-issue.

activities.message:
I don’t want a bounty like some dolphin that’s done a trick. I wanted to report the issue to Twitter and this was the only way possible.

All U.K. Twitter users are still open to the attack, the fact most countries use a shortcode isn’t an excuse to mark it as some duplicate. Writing a blog in 2012 also doesn’t fix the problem... I know you wrote a blog that’s what turned me from concerned person trying to report an issue to exposing the coverup. 17 million U.K. users could be vulnerable and you are trying to brush the issue under the carpet. Not to mention India, Australia etc Failing to address an issue over a 10 year period means you are complicit with this coverup and do not intend to weed out the root cause of so much crime. I’ve got other people coming to me now with different stories.

Regarding timescales, I’m not the one selling my services to Twitter claiming “because hackers never sleep” along with my opening hours. 

In recap:

Me: “you can do bad things”

Me: “wtaf, you fucking knew you could do bad things???!!!!!”

You: “yeah but it’s only every user in India, Australia and U.K. and Italy with a phone linked, we’ve already wrote a blog, what more you want”

activities.message: Thanks, @antisocial_eng. As noted in the 2012 blog post, we do offer users who have registered via longcodes the ability to set a PIN for SMS interactions: https://help.twitter.com/en/using-twitter/sms-pin (note, the PIN option is only available for accounts whose phone number is associated with a longcode-only network). If you believe this PIN option is not working for longcode network users or that PINs for long code users can otherwise be bypassed, please let us know. Otherwise, this is a known issue and limitation inherent to the global SMS ecosystem.

You are wrong. 

My phone is O2 in the U.K... this is a provider/phone number associated with a shortcode. I do not have the ability to activate pin protection because it is a phone number that is associated with a shortcode. But you can still use the 3UK number to target my account. Anyone in the world (tested on all U.K. networks) can use the Three number. 

You’ve fixed the issue across the world then left it wide open and unchanged at the same time.

You have logic flaws in your patches for logic flaws.

I am done, do what you want and I’ll work on adding pressure around this issue and your cover up so innocent users are safer from scams.

@antisocial_eng, we have fixed a bug that allowed spoofing of certain shortcode-associated accounts via the UK longcode. As of now, only longcode users should continue to be able to be spoofed (as was the case in 2012).

We also confirmed that you are correct that the current UI does not expose an option to set a PIN for longcode users. Legacy longcode users who previously set a PIN will continue to be protected by it, but current longcode users are unable to add a new PIN via the current UI.

The bulk of our users have shortcode-based accounts, and these accounts are protected against this type of spoofing. We're continuing to explore potential long term fixes to the SMS spoofing risk for our remaining longcode users. But since longcode users have been susceptible to this kind of spoofing for as long as Twitter has existed, we're not yet sure if or when we'll be able to fully resolve that risk.

activities.message:
@antisocial_eng we did some more checking and the PIN option is still available, but only to accounts associated with one of the Twitter longcodes. This is likely why you don't see it. That said, coupled with our previous fix, you should not be able to find an account that is both spoofable and for which setting a PIN is NOT an option. I.e. all remaining longcode accounts should be able to set a PIN. If you believe you can still spoof any account that is NOT capable of setting a PIN via the web interface as described at https://help.twitter.com/en/using-twitter/sms-pin, please let us know.

We're still evaluating potential long term mitigations related to SMS spoofing in general, but we plan to close this report soon as we believe we are back to the point where the mitigations published in the 2012 blog post are working again. The vast majority of Twitter users are on shortcode networks and should not be spoofable. The small minority of users on longcode networks should have the option of setting a PIN to prevent spoofing. If you believe this is not correct, please let us know.

We consider this issue to be fixed now. If you believe you are still able to bypass the protections discussed in https://blog.twitter.com/engineering/en_us/a/2012/twitter-and-sms-spoofing.html, please feel free to open a new report. As a reminder for future reports, please test using only test accounts you control and refrain from discussing the issue publicly until we have a chance to resolve it. For a full list of our program rules, see https://hackerone.com/twitter.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!
